tagDescription: examined by Mr.Sherwood. Evidence regarding dissatisfaction of settlers who went away of themselves.
Address of Attorney General Robinson to Jury.
to the Wintering Partners of the North West Company and their reply. Regarding the establishment of the Red River colony.Attitude of the North West Company.
Oaths to be taken by Governors.

to Bathurst. Enclosing copies of various depositions,and requesting his attention to letters written by Simon McGillivray and others,showing responsibility of North West Company for attacks on Red River Settlement.
Appendix E. Bill found against Paul Brown.

(Book D.) Transcript or narrative of proceedings at York,U.C. on prosecutions for crimes in the Indian Territories.Murder of Governor Semple at Red River,19 June,1816.Arraignment of John Severight,Alex.McKenzie and others.
Reply by Mr.Sherwood.argument as to malus animus and state of irritation between adherents of the two companies.Regarding principals and accessories.

to Bathurst. Documents show matter to be much more important than a trade dispute.Charges are of agression and outrage. Further statement of Lord Selkirk's case.Refers to Warrants for his apprehension.Principal aim of North West Company. Information regarding Jean B. Blondin,charged to arrest Lord Selkirk.
Appendix S. R.Semple to John Pritchard. Regarding the removal of Fort Daer. Seizure of Hudson's Bay Company goods by North Westers. John McLeod's services.
Appendix H. Bill found against Cuthbert Grant,et al.
Appendix P. Great Seal instrument regarding the trial of Paul Brown.
examined by Mr.Stuart and cross examined by Solicitor General Charles Marshall.
Opinion on the case.
Statement regarding North West Company aggressions.
Documents referred to in the letters. A.Jasper/Vandersluys and james C.McTavish. Information regarding the seizure of Fort William by Lord Selkirk and others,14 August.
Correspondence with Lord Bathurst,1817-18. J.Halkett to Bathurst. Forwarding statement regarding Red River Settlement and requesting personal perusal.
to Bathurst. Regarding the charge of felony against Lord Selkirk,founded on Deposition of Vandersluys and McTavish.
Examnination of John P.Bourke by the Attorney General; cross-examined by Mr.Sherwood.Objection by Attorney General and reply.Argument.
Opinion regarding indictments before the Grand Jury.
Appendix A.A. Notice from Miles McDonell to North West Company to quit the post and premises in the vicinity of Carleton House.
Opinion of Chief Justice Powell regarding provocation and aggressions.
Statement of charge by Solicitor General Boulton for theft of arms and cannon from Lord Selkirk's house.
Opinion on the right of the Attorney General to examine witnesses in presence of the Grand Jury.

Continuation of trials. Argument of Mr. Stuart for the defense. Inadmisibility of confession as evidence. Exception to jurisdiction of Court. Hudson Bay territory within the limits of "Canada" as finally ceded in 1783. Bearing of Act of 1774. Alleged offense cimmitted in Upper Canada,out of jurisdiction of Court.Contention of Mr.Valliere de St.Real as to Act of 1774, and limits of Upper Canada. Reply of Attorney General.Mr.Stuart's answer: Act of 1774 temporary; Act of 1791 permanent. Decision of Chief Justice Sewell against defence as to above Acts. Charge to Jury.Verdict of Jury.Protest by Mr.Stuart. Argument in Court ad to verdict.Mr.Stuart's objections. Motion for now trial and in arrest of judgment.Arguments of H.M.Vanfelson and Stuart.Decisions of Judges.Reply of Attorney General.Further arguments in support of motion. Insistence on irregularity of confession made by prisoner.Question of boundaries debarred by Bench. Arguments in support of arrest of judgment.Incompetence of Court to try offences committed in Indian Territory.Bearing of Act of 1791 (43 Geo.III cap.138). Omission of "Kung's Dominions" and prisoner's allegiance fatal to individual. Question as to England'stitle to possession of Indian Territories.Reply of Attorney General; of Solicitor General. Mr.Stuart's reply to both. Judgment of Court-motion refused.Sentence of death against prisoner.
to Halkett. Acknowledges receipt of foregoing letter and documents.Matter regarded as a dispute between two companies; to be submitted to a Commision.
to Mr.Robertson. Regarding opposition of North West Company and resistance by force.
Point raised by Mr.Sherwood regarding the decision of the Jury on the whole case- the boundaries of Upper Canada.
Letter to Governor and Council of Red River.Regardng commissions of Magistracy,establishment of Judicature.
Extracts of various Statutes respecting Plantations.
to Mr.Robertson. Opinion on verbal promises of Company's servants,and obligations of latter.

Indictment of Charles de Reinhart,Archibald McLellan and others.Address of Attorney General. Examination of Mr. Coltman,Mr.Bouchette and Hubert Faye, by Solicitor General Charles Marshall, and of J.B.Lapointe by Attorney General Uniacke.
Scarlett,Bell,etc. Opinions regarding Hudson's Bay case.
examined by Mr.Stuart,Mr.Coltman by Vanfelson. Louis Nolin and Miles McDonell examined by Attorney General Uniacke.
Draft of Act of Parliament regarding Voyageurs.

Examination of Miles McDonell by Attorney General.Cross-examination by Mr.Sherwood.Question as to Commissions as Governor and Magistrate; issue of warrant to recover cannon.Question as to Red River colony being outside of the two provinces of Canada; as to house being Lord Selkirk's dwelling.
Examination of Robert Gunn by the Solicitor General; cross-examination by Mr.Sherwood as to dissatisfaction of settlers; cannon to be used to prevent their leaving. Reasons for recovering the cannon.
Headings for Hudson's Bay jurisdictions, by J.Miller.
(Book E.) Report of the trial of John Cooper and Hugh Bannerman on an indictment for robbery; George Campbell and others.
examined by Mr. Vanfelson.
to Sherbrooke. On the same subject.
P.C. Pambrun, formerly Lieutenant in Voltigeur Corps of Lower Canada. Copy of narrative of affairs at Red River.
Examination of James McTavish by Mr.Stuart.
F.D.Huerter,late Acting Sergeant Major and clerk in the de Meuron Regiment. Copy of narrative of events at Red River.
Plea of not guilty.Further postponement.
(Book D.) Appendix A.Commission of Oyer and Terminer. Appendix B.
List of law opinions on Hudson's Bay affairs.
Jury returned verdict of "Not Guilty",and were dismissed.
examined by Mr.Sherwood regarding the taking of the cannon.
Regarding North West Company property found at Fort Douglas.
Deposition on the attacks at Red River.
Examination of Michael Heden by Attorney General Robinson.
Appendix F. Bill found against George Campbell et al.
Regarding the issue of a warrant by Lord Selkirk for the seizure of arms at Fort William.
Memorandum from Blackstone as to proprietory colonies, rights,etc.
Appendix V.Great Seal instrument on trial of John McLaughlin.
Examination of Donald McCoy by Solicitor and Attorney General.
Examination of John P.Bourk by Attorney General.
Narratives and Memorials connected with the trials.
Appendix C. Bill found against Cuthbert Grant,et al.
Appendix L.Proclamation by Governor Miles McDonell, 8 January,1814.
General instructions to Colonial Governors.

to Bathurst. Referring to Sir J.C.Sherbrooke's proclamation of 3 May. Submits circumstances shewing charges to be premature and unjust. No employment of unauthorized military force. Facts in connection with engagement of discharged soldiers of de Meuron and Waterville regiments.
to Halkett. Acknowledging receipt of letter.
to Sherbrooke. Regarding law officers.
Defence. Examination of Nicholas Ducharme by Vanfelson. Cross examination by Uniacke.
to J.D.Cameron (Appendix O.) Believes Robertson will not dare to insult Bois Brules.Halfbreeds to assemble in Spring.Has great hopes of success against Red River Colony.
Solicitor General Boulton's charge. Motion for discharge of Hon.W.McGillivray refused.
to Halkett. Replies to letter of 21 February.Unable to enter into explanations of measures adopted by Government.

to Bathurst. Defends himself against charge implied in Mr.Goulburn's letter; intended to give,not asks for,explanations. Inevitable result of conviction prevalent in Canada regarding instructions alluded to.
Speechs by Solicitor General Boulton and Attorney General Robinson for prosecution.
Draft instructions on jurisdiction.(Not sent.)
Examination of John Smith by the Solicitor General.
cross-examined by Mr.Sherwood.Objection by Attorney General.
Appendix K. Against George Campbell.

to Bathurst. Reference to Mr. Goulburn's letter of 1 September. Regarding Lord Selkirk's satisfaction with Commission appointed to determine points in dispute. Subjoins Sir H.Sherbrooke's letter to Selkirk of 30 October,1816,regarding conduct of Commissioners, to be laid before His Majesty's Government.Missive of Proclamation by North West Company.Extraordinary Circular issued by W.B.Coltman.Again requests attention to Warrants issued against Selkirk.Submits Documents F. Invalidity of Warrant.Orders said to have been sent to Canada to institute criminal, proceedings against Selkirk.
Deposition regarding the destruction of the Red River Settlement by Duncan Cameron and North West Company servants.

(Book C.) Transcript of narrative of the proceedings at York,U.C. on prosecutions for trials in the Indian Territories.Address of Attorney General Uniacke regarding the situation of the prisoners Brown and Boucher who were acquitted the previous day.
to ---.Is in possession of North West Company fort. Fort Douglas in state of defence.
Opinion on case regarding aggressions of North West Company against Red River settlers.
Sealed instruments against Hugh Gilles,John McDonald, Simon Fraser and Alex.McKenzie.
(Book C.) Argument of Arch. McLellan. Protest by Mr.Stuart for defence,against continuance of trials until settlement of Court's Jurisdiction,and competence to decide limits of Upper Canada.
Defence speech by Mr. Sherwood. Tresspass,not larceny nor robbery.
Appendix B.B. Notice to Andrew Poitras, of North West Company, to quit the post at Riviere a la Sourie.
Appendix G. Bill found against George Campbell et al.

to Lord Liverpool. Submitting his case to his consideration.Reasons for appealing direct to him,rather than to Colonial Department. Encloses copy of correspondence between Colonial Office and Mr.Halkett. Grounds of complaint against law officers of Crown in Canada.Statement of case against North West Company on lawlessness and aggressions; their opposition to the Red River Settlement.Narrative of events.Regarding Royal Proclamation of May,1817. Hasty and unfair judgement of the whole question. Injustice to himself individually.Pervision of the commission of special enquiry to party ends. Mr.Coltman's dealings with Governor Semple's murderers; his refusal to grant warrants.Bias in favour of North West Company. Restitution of property.Undue sanction of former occupancy.Important witnesses present in London.Small porportion of those indicted brought to trial.Necessity of enquiry into recent judicial proceedins in Canada.
to A.McDonell.(Appendix M.) Warning him of consequences of any attack on Hudson's Bay Company.
Charge to Grand Jury.
Law opinions on Red River affairs.
examined.Settlers not allowed to express dissatisfaction nor to leave.
Examination of Michael Kilbride by the Attorney General; cross-examination by Mr. Sherwood regarding removal of cannon to the North West Company fort.
Appendix D. Bill found against George Campbell,et al.
Deposition regarding attacks on Red River Settlement by servants of the North West Company.

to Sherbrooke. Submitting petitions from persns indicted,asking for trial in May. Nature of charges; motives for bringing them before Court of King's Bench. Noli Prosequi asked for. Proposed change of venue.
to Selkirk. Observations on Hudson's Bay Company jurisdiction.
Examination of Great Seal instruments setting out offences by Chief Justice Powell.
Appendix C.C. R.Semple to P.C.Pambrun. Order to proceed to Brandon House.Instructions in case of hostilities by Halfbreeds.
(Appendix E.) Warrant for arrest,trial and execution of Charles de Reinhard.

Defence. Examination of James Toomey,Hugh Swords,William Wallace, James Pinkman,Martin Jordan,Francois Taupier,----Peltier,William Morrison, Francois Bouche,Michael Martin,Mr.Henry,James Leith, Hon.William McGillivray,John Mezani,Hugh Bannerman,Mrs. Winnifred McNolty, by Mr.Sherwood.
Speech by Levius P.Sherwood for defence.Question of evidence against absent principals in relation to accessories.
to Selkirk. Observations on judicial instructions proposed.
Address by Attorney General Uniacke to the Jury.
Examination of Francois Taupier by Mr.Valliere.

Examination of Hector McLeod by the Attorney General. Cross-examination by Mr.Sherwood as to dissatisfaction of settlers and use of cannon to prevent their leaving. Re-examination by Attorney General.Destruction of Settlement by cannon taken.Necessity of establishing Animus furandi.
to J.Miller. Enclosing heads of abstracts of laws of England for guidance of Hudson's Bay Company servants.
Appendix Q. Regarding trial of Francois Boucher.
Examination of Mr. Crebassa by Mr.Stuart.
Hudson's Bay Company resolutions regarding judicature.
Examination of Hugh McLean,John Pritchard, Patrick Corcoran,Pierre Pambrun,Louis Nolin and Frederick Heurter by the Attorney General,with cross-examination by Mr Sherwood.
to Selkirk. Relating to the use, by law officers of the Crown, of assistance of Lord Selkirk's advisers, in pending prosecutions.
Narrative of Red River Settlement.
Proposed line of defence.Examination of Bourke resumed.
Mr.Justice Boulton's charge to the Jury.
Clauses of the Act of Parliament relating to the Provinces of Canada.
Copy of Voyageur Act,Lower Canada.
Acts relating to Plantation trade,before 7th and 8th of William III.

to A.McDonell. (Appendix N.) Cannot agree to Mr. Robertson's journey or to delagation of his powers. Will meet him at spot to be agreed upon. Will respect his personal property unless he begins hostilities. Is quite prepared for any scheme of retaliation.
Cross examination of Lapointe by Mr. Valfelson.Examination of Augustin Poirier by Attorney General,and of Mr. Heurter.Question of presence of Alex.McDonald.
Bill of Grand Jury against George Campbell,John Cooper,et al,for removal of cannon,etc. from Lord Selkirk's house.
Appendix D.D. General Seal Instrument regarding the trial of George Campbell, et al.
Appendix U. Great Seal instrument regarding the trial of John Severight for the murder of Governor Semple.
to George Auldjo. Opinion regarding matters relating to Hudson's Bay affairs.
Opinion on warrant for arrest of Lord Selkirk and his right to plead his privilege in Canada for trial by his Peers.
Appendix R. O.Holte to  John Pritchard. Referring to the fitting out of a Schooner to intercept North West Company canoes.
Objection by Attorney General Robinson. Examination of MilesMcDonell regarding the issue of the proclamation. Cross-examination by Mr.Sherwood regarding the validity of the Commission.
Clauses on the Hudson's Bay Company grant affecting settlers.
Appendix J. Against Paul Brown.
